contents.context:
South Korea reported 35 new COVID-19 cases on Monday, 30 of which were from community-based transmissions.
While cases linked to the Bucheon logistics center have been slowing down, cases related to religious gatherings are starting to grow within the metropolitan area.
The Korean government on Monday urged the public to refrain from face-to-face religious gatherings as 24 of the new cases were linked to these events.

"If face-to-face gatherings are inevitable, please limit the size of the gathering to ensure sufficient distance between participants. Make sure to wear a mask and wash hands frequently. Please refrain from singing and shouting, as that could cause droplet infection, and it is best to avoid large group meals."

So far, there has been one death related to the cluster infection from recent religious gatherings and another patient is in a critical condition.
Three additional cases related to the Bucheon logistics center were reported on Monday bringing the total number of related cases to 1-hundred-12.
Of these, 74 were the center's employees while the rest were infected through contact with them.
Describing logistics centers and telemarketing offices as high risk groups for infection, the head of the central disease control headquarters also called for measures to create safer environments for these businesses.
She added that distancing in daily life in schools and education facilities is also crucial as they could potentially become the roots of further cluster infections.
South Korea's total confirmed cases now stand at 11,503, with the death toll at 2-hundred-71 after one additional death on Monday.
Kim Sung-min, Arirang News
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korean reports 35 new COVID-19 cases; 24 linked to religious gatherings
Updated: 2020-06-01 17:07:20 KST

contents.context:
"A QR code, or quick-response code, looks kind of like a standard barcode, but its complicated matrix of black and white squares gives it a lot more storage capacity.
From now on, this will be the way South Korea keeps track of people visiting places where there's a higher risk of infection."

Visitors will download a QR provider app like Naver.
Once they fill out their personal details, an instant QR code is generated.
There, your name, phone number, and the time you enter the place are automatically recorded.
The venue will scan the code to send the data for internet storage.

Due to privacy concerns, the information will be divided between the QR provider and a public institution, and will only be recombined for contact tracing during outbreaks.
All data will be deleted after four weeks.

This electronic entry log is currently undergoing a one-week trial in 19 selected facilities in the capital area.
But it will be adopted nationwide starting from June 10th.

And from then, it will become mandatory for places with a high risk of infection, including bars, nightclubs, singing rooms, and fitness classes like Zumba and spinning sessions.

Other venues like churches and movie theaters will also be recommended to use the QR codes.

The QR code-based entry logs first emerged as a tool to better track visitors and contain cluster infections,.. after some visitors to virus-hit clubs in Itaewon had written their information inaccurately.
Lee Kyung-eun, Arirang News.
Reporter : kelee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Nightclubs, bars and singing rooms in S. Korea required to use QR codes to log visitors starting this month
Updated: 2020-06-01 17:06:56 KST

contents.context:
President Moon Jae-in has vowed to use South Korea's full fiscal capacity to overcome the COVID-19 crisis, calling for parliamentary cooperation for the swift passage of a third extra budget.
Chairing an emergency economic council session on Monday, Moon said that there must be an economic rebound in the second half of the year, as the South Korean economy contracted 1.4 percent on-quarter in the first three months of this year.


"The government earmarked an all-time high single extra budget as part of its drastic finance injection policies for the latter half of the year, which will be submitted to the parliament this week.
I ask for lawmakers to cooperate in swiftly screening and passing the budget to recover our economy as soon as possible."

The ruling Democratic Party and the government vowed to pass the third extra budget by as early as June.

"We will work to pass the third budget within the June extraordinary session as soon as we finish finalizing the structure of the 21st National Assembly."

Though the exact size of the budget is yet to be announced, it is widely expected to top 24 billion U.S. dollars.
It will provide over 8 billion dollars to help small enterprises, and 25 billion dollars to stabilize bond and stock markets.
The budget will also be used to create around 550,000 jobs in the digital sector, and to expand the social safety net.

The government will also raise the age for free flu shots so that an extra 2.4 million under-18s will be able to get the vaccines.

"Once the budget gets passed, the ruling party and the government hope to implement 75 percent of it within three months.
The opposition also agreed on the need for a large-scale extra budget, and claimed that it will cooperate if the proposal is deemed reasonable."
Kim Mok-yeon, Arirang News.
Reporter : mokyeon90@gmail.com
contents.headline:
President Moon urges parliament to swiftly pass third extra budget
Updated: 2020-06-01 17:06:27 KST

contents.context:
At the emergency economic council today, President Moon Jae-in defined the "Korean New Deal" as the nation's future vision for an overall transformation not just a single project or a task to bring the economy out of the woods.
Here's the President.

The government will push for a Korean version of the New Deal based on two pillars, a Digital New Deal and a Green New Deal, for South Korea's future. We will transform the economy into one that leads rather than follows and create new opportunities through massive job creation.

Partly funded by the government's proposed third extra budget, the government will seek new projects and exand the size of its investment for the Korean New Deal with a comprehensive plan to come in July.
The president added that he will turn the country's quarantine industry into a new engine for exports, and foster new industries, such as bio and future cars, to prepare for a post-COVID-19 era.
Reporter : kimmj@arirang.com
contents.headline:
President Moon says Korean New Deal is a new national development strategy
Updated: 2020-06-01 17:04:43 KST

contents.context:
The city of Seoul is going to help some 2,500 low-income households and another 300 newlywed couples get homes to live in under long-term leases.
In Korea, such leases require a big lump-sum deposit, which can be many times an individual's salary, so the city is going to provide up to 95 percent of it.
For low-income households, the limit for the total deposit will be about 180-thousand U.S. dollars.
For newlyweds, it has to be under about 490-thousand.
The actual owner of the home will sign the lease with the city, which then sublets the home to the tenant.
The lease is for two years and can be renewed up to nine times if the tenant remains eligible.
Applications will be accepted starting next Wednesday at local community centers.
Reporter : jychoi@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Seoul to pay lease deposits for 2,800 low-income households and newlyweds
Updated: 2020-06-01 17:03:44 KST

contents.context:
To help the country overcome COVID-19, the government and the ruling Democratic Party have agreed a third supplementary budget proposal, the largest such budget ever.
In a meeting held at the National Assembly on Monday, the two sides vowed to pass the third extra budget by as early as June.

"The government stressed the necessity of the budget and called for the parliament's support in getting it passed swiftly. We will work to pass the third budget within the June extraordinary session as soon as we finish finalizing the structure of the 21st National Assembly."

Though the exact size of the budget is yet to be announced, it is widely expected to surpass 24 billion U.S. dollars.
Much of the third extra budget will be used to cope with the economic fallout from the pandemic, especially in supporting the nation's businesses.
The two sides plan to inject up to 8.1 billion dollars for emergency funding of small enterprises, and establish funds worth 25 billion dollars to stabilize the bond and stock markets."

The ruling party will also use the budget to pursue its number one campaign pledge, which is to expand public wifi to lessen telecommunications costs for the general public.
The party seeks to install 41,000 public wifi points by 2022.
Parts of the budget will also be used to create around 550,000 emergency jobs in the digital sector, and to expand support for unstable jobs and the social safety net.

The budget will also raise the age for free flu shots so that an extra 2.4 million teenagers aged 18 and below will be able to receive the vaccines.
The two sides plan to finance the massive budget by restructuring how the country spends its tax revenue, and will make up the rest of it through national debt.

"Once the budget gets passed, the ruling party and the government hope to implement 75 percent of it within three months.
The opposition also agreed on the need for a large-scale extra budget, and claimed that it will cooperate if the proposal is deemed reasonable."
Kim Mok-yeon, Arirang News.
Reporter : mokyeon90@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Ruling Party, gov't agree on record 3rd extra budget to overcome COVID-19
Updated: 2020-06-01 14:40:21 KST

contents.context:
Some daycare centers in South Korea have reopened three months after they were closed due to the outbreak.
But those in Seoul, Incheon and Gyeonggi-do Province will remain shut until the number of new infections comes down.
Those that have reopened have to follow guidelines like staff wearing face masks and checking everyone's temperature.
The government decided to reopen daycares because of the strain their closure was putting on their emergency child care services for parents who need to work.
Meanwhile, the country reported 35 new cases of COVID-19 on Monday, concentrated in the region near Seoul.
There was an additional death as well, bringing the death toll to 271.
Reporter : tommyjang@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Daycare centers in some part of S. Korea resume Monday
Updated: 2020-06-01 13:19:32 KST

contents.context:
From Monday the 5-day rotation system imposed in South Korea to regulate the amount of protective face mask that can be sold will be lifted.
People wanting to purchase masks will be able to do so any day of the week.
The Ministry of Food and Drug Safety says the supply in the country has stabilized thanks to an increase in the daily production to 14-million face masks.
Young Koreans, under the age of 18 will be able to buy up to 5 masks a week, as they have started or are due to restart in line with the school reopening season.
The rest of the population, will still be limited to 3 masks a week.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
S. Korea eases protective face mask purchase restrictions starting June 1
Updated: 2020-06-01 10:14:39 KST

Gov't COVID-19 briefing
Updated: 2020-06-01 10:10:48 KST

contents.context:
South Korea reported 35 new COVID-19 cases on Monday, amid cluster infections in the metropolitan area.
Of them, 30 were community transmissions, with 18 in Incheon …and eleven in Gyeonggi-do Province.
Five were imported.
The total number of cases is eleven,five-hundred-three.
There was one new death, bringing the death toll to two-hundred-71.
Over 24-thousand people are being tested, and seventeen more have been discharged after making recovering.
Starting today, high-risk facilities like nightclubs and singing rooms will be required to use QR codes to log customers’ visits as part of contact tracing efforts.
Reporter :
contents.headline:
S. Korea reports 35 new COVID-19 cases on Monday, 1 new death
Updated: 2020-06-01 10:02:20 KST

contents.context:
The government and the ruling Democratic Party have agreed a record third supplementary budget proposal to overcome COVID-19.
In a meeting on Monday, Finance minister Hong Nam-ki vowed to submit the government's budget proposal to parliament by Thursday and the ruling party promised efforts to swiftly pass the third budget within June.
The two sides plan to implement 75 percent of the budget within the next three months.
It will be used to cope with the economic fallout from the pandemic by injecting up to 8.1 billion U.S. dollars for emergency funding of small enterprises, as well as installing 41,000 public wifi points by 2022.
The budget will also be used to develop treatments and vaccines and build up the nation's biotech industry.
Reporter : mokyeon90@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Ruling Party, gov't agree to record 3rd extra budget to overcome COVID-19
Updated: 2020-06-01 10:00:50 KST

contents.context:
President Moon Jae-in will chair a session of the emergency economic council this afternoon to discuss the government's proposed third extra budget that'll be used to tackle COVID-19.
His chairing of today's meeting which comes in over a month is likely to highlight the need for another supplementary budget amid the economic crisis, and to fine tune the specifics of the so-called Korea New Deal.
Another topic on the table is South Korea's economic policy direction for the second half of 2020.
The government will likely submit the budget bill to the National Assembly for deliberation later this week.
Reporter : kimmj@arirang.com
contents.headline:
President Moon to chair emergency economic council to discuss extra budget plan
Updated: 2020-06-01 10:00:32 KST
